Brexit two years on: has the UK â€˜taken back control'?

25/02/2022

The Nouse team analyse the ripple effect of Brexit two years on

Image by Jenny Goodfellow

By Hannah Boyle

Two years on from theÂ U.Kâ€™s official exit from the EuropeanÂ Union, the ripple effect continuesÂ to be influential across the country.Â With the added complications created by Covid-19, we explore the lasting legacy of Brexit in our key sectors.

NHS

Despite two years passing sinceÂ the UKâ€™s break with the EU, Brexit stillÂ causes uncertainty for the NHS and social care sectors. There continues to be aÂ general concern that there has been noÂ improvement to health care as promised, including the Â£350 million promised by Vote Leaveâ€™s Brexit bus, with theÂ most challenging being staffing. Leaving the EUâ€™s single market has broughtÂ a halt to the free movement of workersÂ between the EU and UK.Â This has led to large numbers ofÂ non-British workers leaving the NHS asÂ a result of new laws requiring all workers from EEA nations to declare theirÂ right to work in the UK through the EUÂ Settlement Scheme, therefore there isÂ now a huge shortfall in NHS staffing.Â According to Kingsfund, despite aÂ pledge to hire 5, 000 more NHS nursesÂ in the next few years, the new immigration laws place difficult barriers whenÂ hiring from EEA countries. Whilst it isÂ still relatively easy for the NHS to hireÂ staff from non-EEA countries, the newÂ laws have definitely made the UK a lessÂ attractive place to international healthÂ workers seeking employment and makeÂ it more difficult than before to hire staffÂ to resolve the growing workforce crisis.

Katy Leverett, Travel Editor

Northern Ireland

The Northern Ireland Protocol following the UKâ€™s withdrawal from theÂ EU has created significant trading implications, with checks implementedÂ on goods crossing the Irish Sea. LongÂ delays at the port, particularly for animal and plant-based products, has added around four hours to the turnaroundÂ time per lorry since the Protocol cameÂ into effect. As a result, complianceÂ costs for businesses have noticeably increased too. Despite this, Northern Ireland hasÂ enjoyed free access to twin marketsÂ during the transition period, spear-heading a 60 percent increase in tradeÂ between Northern Ireland and the Republic in the first nine months of lastÂ year. Labour shortages have been oneÂ barrier though as 18,000 EU migrantsÂ have left Northern Ireland since 2016.Â The pandemic has exacerbated thisÂ by halting the usual flow of EuropeanÂ workers leading to job vacancy rates ofÂ up to 15 percent in industries like the meat processing sector.Â Yet, a more sobering concern is theÂ aggravation of tensions in Northern Ireland, with inspection duties temporarily suspended at Larne and Belfast portsÂ last year after staff faced death threats.Â DUP minister Edwin Poots orderedÂ checks to be suspended again duringÂ February this year, as his colleague firstÂ minister Paul Givan resigned in protestÂ over the Protocol. This is likely to causeÂ serious problems for Britainâ€™s relationship with the EU, particularly after theÂ resignation of Lord Frost as Brexit minister. There are indications NorthernÂ Ireland could see its first Sinn Fein firstÂ minister in the May elections too, evoking fears that political conflict may return to Northern Ireland if separationist policies continue.

Josh Rutland, Deputy Politics Editor

Erasmus

Erasmus has been seen as an unexpected casualty of the Brexit process,Â with the United Kingdom leaving theÂ EU and declining to take part in theÂ scheme as an associated third country, replaced by the â€˜Turing Schemeâ€™, designed by the British Government toÂ allow up to 35,000 students to workÂ and travel internationally during theirÂ education. While the Erasmus schemeÂ was limited to travel based in EuropeanÂ states, the Turing Scheme aims to expand the network of travel further internationally and offers varying amountsÂ of funding to match the destinationÂ chosen.Â However, the Turing Scheme hasÂ not been without complication, it isÂ available currently for organisations toÂ access, without students being able toÂ access it on an individual basis.Â Funding is not available for teaching staff or college staff which wouldÂ have previously been accepted underÂ Erasmus. While the Turing SchemeÂ has approved 372 projects for fundingÂ and has been guaranteed for furtherÂ funding for the next three years, lackÂ of publicity and barriers to individualÂ applications continue to challenge students accessing international academicÂ opportunities. Ultimately, the schemeÂ risks becoming a symbol of patriotism,Â which just misses the mark.

HannahÂ Boyle, Deputy Politics Editor

International Trade

Brexit has undoubtedly complicated the ability of UK businesses to import and export easily. Businesses nowÂ have to prove that goods exported toÂ the EU meet strict requirements whichÂ state that a certain percentage of theÂ product has to be made within the UKÂ or EU. Such complex rules has madeÂ it more difficult for the UK to recoverÂ from the effects of Covid-19, as theÂ UKâ€™s flow of trade relative to GDP is atÂ its lowest level since 2009, whilst EUÂ countries have largely recovered from where they were in March 2020. Ministers have sought to leverageÂ the opportunity of no longer being inÂ the single market by striking trade dealsÂ across emerging economies, in Asia Pacific especially. However, the 64 dealsÂ signed so far are roll over deals that replicate pre-Brexit conditions and deliverÂ no new benefits. Even the genuinelyÂ new deals with Australia and New Zealand, centre-pieces of the Conservativeâ€™s election campaign, are estimatedÂ to grow UK GDP by only 0.08 percentÂ over the next ten years. Nonetheless,Â the UK witnessed in 2021 the shareÂ of its international trade with non-EUÂ countries become greater than those inÂ the EU for the first time; leaving openÂ the possibility that, for all of the dislocation suffered, the UK is now takingÂ advantage of new markets.

Josh Cole, Deputy Business Editor

Travel Abroad

It is fair to say that in regards toÂ post-Brexit holiday plans, uncertaintyÂ over travelling abroad has not dissipated. The many grievances peopleÂ once had regarding the severity of visaÂ requirements when travelling to countries in Europe have been partiallyÂ eased but questions still need to be answered on how the post-Brexit plan willÂ affect our everyday lives. Britons travelling abroad to EUÂ countries within the â€˜Schengen Zoneâ€™Â for more than 90 days will soon requireÂ a form of travel authorisationÂ pass in the form of ETIAS, anÂ EU-based scheme. ETIASÂ is essentially a system thatÂ British passport holdersÂ will pay into regularly inÂ order to gain travel accessÂ to all 26 EU countries. TheÂ same travel authorisationÂ will apply to EU visitorsÂ to the UK too and theÂ government haveÂ said they will haveÂ this set up over theÂ course of this year.Â By 2025, electronic passes willÂ be needed even justÂ for short businessÂ trips and holidays.Â Visas, however, willÂ soon be needed onÂ a long-term basis. ItÂ remains to be seenÂ what the longerÂ term future willÂ look like for travelling abroad but oneÂ thing is clear â€“ sacrifices will have to be madeÂ by everyone.

Max Abdulgani

Fishing

Youâ€™d be hard-pushed to find anÂ industry more impacted by BrexitÂ than fishing. The 2021 post-BrexitÂ trade deal has stipulated that licencesÂ are needed on both sides in order forÂ fisheries to function on the right sideÂ of EU law. Boats from EU memberÂ states must have licences to fish in UKÂ waters, with the same being true forÂ UK boats looking to fish in the EU. This has become the latest in a longÂ line of micro-rows between FranceÂ and the UK since the latter voted toÂ leave the European Union almost sixÂ years ago. The UK and Jersey refusedÂ licences to a number of French boatsÂ last October. The situation souredÂ and led to French fishermen blocking the entry of UK boats to FrenchÂ ports. French President, EmmanuelÂ Macron, addressed the press in November, saying: â€œWe have not got whatÂ we wanted [and] we will not yield.â€And he was right. The EuropeÂ minister for France, Clement Beaune,Â announced two days before Christmas that the French would be relayingÂ their complaints to the specially set-upÂ tribunal for Brexit (dis)agreements. So Brexitâ€™s impact on fishingÂ has thus far been to further complicate an industry already swimming in red tape.

Dom Smith, Sport Editor

Immigration

Immigration is one of the issuesÂ that initially characterised Brexit. Now,Â two years after the UK officially left theÂ European Union, it could be arguedÂ that immigration has become less pre-dominant in our discussions of BrexitÂ despite having a profound impact.Â Since leaving the EU, the British government has introduced a new points-based immigration system which itÂ says will allow more skilled workers toÂ enter the UK and begin working here.Â Before January 2021, EU citizensÂ were free to move and work within theÂ UK; since then, any EU citizen coming to live or work in the UK will needÂ to apply for a visa. This shows the realÂ impact Brexit has had on migrants andÂ the desire of the British governmentÂ to have a tighter grip on its borders.Â However, with theÂ combined negative effects of Covid-19Â as well as the complications peopleÂ have experienced applying for settled status in the UK following Brexit,Â employers have found it increasinglyÂ hard to retain foreign staff who leftÂ the UK and are now trying to return.Â Furthermore, the restrictions on low-skilled workers entering the UK afterÂ Brexit has meant that employers, forÂ example in the fruit-picking sector,Â have struggled to maintain enoughÂ workers to meet financial targetsÂ while continuing to operate in theÂ same way as before Brexit.

Arun Kohli, Social Media Director

Sovereignty

A huge portion of theÂ support for Brexit â€“ and significant roadblocks in theÂ following negotiation processÂ - stemmed from a desire forÂ the UK to reclaim its nationalÂ sovereignty and have moreÂ control over its own legislation.Â In the two years sinceÂ the UKâ€™s withdrawal, weÂ have seen many changes toÂ British legislation in com-parison to our EU counter-parts, including the particularly notable abolishment of theÂ so-called â€˜tampon taxâ€™ on sanitary products, which the EU requires to be set at 5 percent VAT.Â Such a divergence highlightsÂ the ways in which Brexit BritainÂ has arguably had the ability toÂ change for the better since 2020.Â However, with data protection laws remaining consistent andÂ economic reliance forcing our majorÂ trade industries such as agriculture toÂ remain aligned with the EU in orderÂ to compete, we can begin to questionÂ how effective Brexit has been in â€œtakingÂ back controlâ€ after all.

Hannah Carley, Features Editor
